physDesc.p: (1) The scribe has a particular way of writing the descending stroke in syllables like a [292v6] and yu [292v5]. (2) The glyph ku in [292v7] is most probably a mistake: the scribe changed his mind and decided to write naṉṟāka (“may there be prosperity”) before the invocation to the teacher (kuru vāḻka “may the teacher thrive”). (3) Either the tithi or the nakṣatra recorded in the date are wrong. As it is, the date can correspond to three different days in the Gregorian calendar, although in all the three cases at least one calendrical element is wrong: 24 June 1712 (but the tithi was the 2nd, whereas the colophon records the 7th), 6 July 1772 (but it was a Monday and the nakṣatra was the 12th, whereas the colophon records Tuesday and 8th nakṣatra respectively), 7 July 1772 (but the day was the 27th and the nakṣatra was the 13th, whereas the colophon records the 26th day and the 8th nakṣatra respectively).

div.head: Translation
div.p: On the auspicious day when the Jovian year Ṉantaṉam, the month of Āṉi, the 26th day, the seventh [luna day], Monday come together – and also the constellation of Pūcam –, Tiyākāracaṉ who is in Ciṅkavaṉam fully copied the Makāparatam. Tiyākāracar is the support, Cokkaliṅkam is the support, Mīṉāṭci is the support, Cuppiṟamaṉiyar is the support. Rācentiramūṟti is the support, Aṟam Vaḷattavaḷ [read Vaḷaittavaḷ?] is the support. Vetaṉāyaki is the support. VIctory to the illustrious Rāma. Hari om, may there be prosperity, may the teacher thrive, only the teacher is the support, honour to Keṇapati. The person who reads, the person who listens to this Pāratam ??? (??mai-y-ilaakkiya⟨mum⟩) will in the end obtain even the abode of Kayilācam. The lotus-like feet of Makāleṭcumi are the support.
